description: From Middle English ropen (“to cry out”), from Old English hrōpan (“to shout, proclaim; cry out, scream, howl”), from Proto-Germanic *hrōpaną (“to call, shout, cry”), from Proto-Indo-European *ker-, *kor- (“to caw, crow”). Cognate with Scots roup (“to shout, roar, cry out loudly”), Saterland Frisian roupe (“to call, shout”), Dutch roepen (“to shout, cry out”), German rufen (“to call, cry, shout”), Swedish ropa (“to call, cry out, shout”), Icelandic hrópa (“to cry out”).

verbs.description: roop (third-person singular simple present roops, present participle rooping, simple past and past participle rooped)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, UK dialectal, Northern England, Scotland) To roar; make a great noise.
(transitive, usually with up, dialectal) To make hoarse.
